title: recode_vrs
text: Although new pragmatic platforms (RedCap) currently exist, great deal research data still collected directly excel, easier code variables short form. example, “birth date” commonly coded short form “dob” instead “Date birth”, publication form. applies values variables, “F” “M”, values “Gender” variable, stand “Female” “Male”, respectively. Recoding variables values back publication form inevitable task statistical analysis reporting results. recode_vrs() function helps effortlessly transform collected data publication-ready format using user-supplied data dictionary. Combining recode_vrs() data dictionary ensures consistency recoding research terms across analyses publications one easily forget variable term labelled previous analysis publication. recoded data can used make figures, table one…etc.

title: recode_vrs
text: introduction, referred 4 terms: Variable, “dob”: short form “Date birth” usually used excel sheets.Variable label, “Date birth”: publication form usually encounter publications.Value, “F” “M”, values “Gender” variable.Value label, “Female” “Male”, labels “Gender” values, “F” “M”, respectively. inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) data dictionary ibd_data_dict provided phdcocktail package consists 4 columns, one -described terms.  4 columns required order recode_vrs() function needed. Therefore, user-supplied data dictionaries logically columns!

title: recode_vrs
text: passing data frame raw data data dictionary recode_vrs(), function : Search data dictionary variables labels variables, attach corresponding variables original data frame “label attributes”. attributes can recognized gtsummary::tbl_summary() functions printing. Search data dictionary values labels variables specified vrs argument. values “recoded” corresponding labels. factor argument set TRUE, variables specified vrs argument converted ordered factors, order levels inherited order appearance values data dictionary. ordered factors important desired display values passing resulted data frame functions ggplot2, gtsummary…etc. see recode_vrs() action, make table one ibd_data1 available package: Let’s first view data frame…  can see variables values stored short form. can make table one using data current form, won’t suitable published!  Now let’s recode data frame using recode_vrs(), view new, recoded data frame, name ibd_data_recoded…  can notice three changes new data frame compared original one: Variables labels now attached “attributes” underneath variables names variables corresponding variable label found supplied dictionary. Values replaced labels variables specified vrs argument. Variables specified vrs argument converted ordered factors. Finally, let’s make table one new recoded data…
code: data(ibd_data1, package = "phdcocktail")  View(ibd_data1) library(gtsummary) theme_gtsummary_compact() # to make a compact table  ibd_data1 |>   tbl_summary(include = -"patientid") # we don't need patient IDs in our table ibd_data_recoded <- recode_vrs(data = ibd_data1, data_dictionary = ibd_data_dict, vrs = c("disease_location", "disease_behaviour", "gender"), factor = TRUE)  View(ibd_data_recoded) ibd_data_recoded |>   tbl_summary(include = -"patientid")

what: Some questions that might come to mind…
title: recode_vrs
text: “recode” variables labels? attach labels “label attributes”? recode variables names labels, one change also code subsequent steps analysis variables names changed! Since variable labels needed printing, attaching “attributes” nice way provide publishable names, time preserve original variable names scripting. simply pass variables/values labels manually printing functions gtsummary::tbl_summary()? tedious waste time repeat analysis (maybe several times one analysis!) assuming one working topic/disease. addition, passing labels manually hugely prone errors inconsistencies across analyses papers. functions packages can recode variables/values attach label attributes? Yes, Hmisc::upData(), expss::apply_labels() others….

title: phdcocktail
text: phdcocktail collection functions wrote PhD. functions help: ) effortlessly transform collected data publication-ready format, ii) generate insightful visualizations clinical data, iii) report summary statistics publication-ready format, iv) efficiently export, save reload R objects within framework R projects.

Delete files from the 'output' folder — delete_output
text: folder folder user wishes delete files. default folder 'output'. argument user can specify file deleted. 3 valid character values argument: ) 'except-r' option, delete files except R script data files, ii) '' option, delete files specified folder, iii) 'extensions' option, specify extensions deleted. default behaviour 'except-r'. extensions character vector indicating extensions files user wishes delete. default extensions excel extensions.

title: Export files to the 'output' folder — export_safely
text: data object exported. folder folder object need exported. default 'data' folder within 'output' folder. name name exported file. name provided, file inherit object's name. format format exported file. Default 'xlsx'. overwrite logical indicate whether preexisting files identical names overwritten. Default 'FALSE'. time_in_name logical indicate whether timestamp included file's name. ... argument can passed 'rio::export'

text: message indicating full path exported file.

Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) datasets — ibd_data1
text: 'ibd_data1' 'ibd_data2' two small datasets containing data collected IBD patients, specifically patients Crohn's disease. 'ibd_data2' modified version 'ibd_data1' introducing missing incorrect entries 'L11' column 'disease_location'.

title: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) datasets — ibd_data1
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) datasets — ibd_data1
text: Two data frames 30 rows six columns: patientid Patient ID gender Gender disease_location Disease location disease_behaviour Disease behaviour crp_mg_l C-reactive protein (mg/L) calprotectin_ug_g Faecal calprotectin (ug/g)
